thread.title: Youngstown State's Physical Defense Set The Tone
thread.title_full: Youngstown State's Physical Defense Set The Tone

author: JEREMY HOECK jeremy.hoeck@yankton.net
title: Youngstown State's Physical Defense Set The Tone
text:
VERMILLION – The University of South Dakota football team got an up-close look at what helped Bo Pelini win so many games at Nebraska. 
A physical defense. 
One of the areas USD head coach Joe Glenn referenced – a couple times – after Saturday’s 31-3 Missouri Valley loss to Pelini’s Youngstown State squad was the physical play on the Coyote wide receivers. 
The Penguins came into the game with the nation’s top defense – having allowed an average of 59 yards through the air – and although USD nearly doubled that (119), the Coyote receivers consistently found it challenging to create any space. 
“We couldn’t get off bump, we couldn’t get off whatever they were doing to us,” Glenn said. “And if they’re going to let it go like that, we better find a way to practice against it.” 
The longest play through the air for USD was a 63-yard pass from junior quarterback Ryan Saeger to freshman running back Michael Fredrick, but most of that yardage came after the catch. The next longest? 14 yards, to another running back (Trevor Bouma). 
“That’s just Missouri Valley football, I think,” said Saeger, who completed 9-of-25 passes. “There’s a lot of tugging going on, and their corners did a good job of getting up in their face and not letting them get a clean release.” 
The Coyotes certainly had a chance early to stretch the field, but a deep pass on their first drive was narrowly missed by receiver Eric Shufford (who would catch a team-high three passes). After that point, there were few times when a USD receiver or tight end had much space between them and a defender. 
“It’s totally what you see, it’s kind of vogue in football right now, people get up and get in your face,” Glenn said. “It’s kind of a streetball. And we didn’t handle it.” 
The question now is, how much of that style will the Coyotes see throughout the rest of the Missouri Valley schedule? 
“I don’t think there was anything really different that we’ve seen thus far this year, but we’ll see more of it as the year goes on,” Saeger said. 
“It’s something we have to practice and get better at, I guess.”
